The parts of the screen being hit by electrons

But then colour television was invented -- giving

138.text:
The principal is very simple: instead of using
a beam of electrons to create lines, the plasma

143.text:
screen uses what are in effect tiny, quick-acting
fluorescent light cells to form a picture.

151.text:
In a modern colour plasma display, each pixel
has three of these florescent lights, one

156.text:
in each primary colour, and fires them intelligently
to create the desired colour in the picture.

162.text:
LCD televisions, the sworn enemy of Plasma
systems according to the bloke in the telly

167.text:
use individual LCD 'shutters' for each pixel
to create a similar effect.

174.text:
A plasma is basically just an electrically
conductive gas that contains both free-flowing

180.text:
ions (positively charged atoms) and electrons
(which are negatively charged.)

186.text:
If you introduce more electrons by putting
a voltage through this gas then these will

190.text:
begin to collide with atoms, knocking off
other electrons and turning them into ions.

197.text:
Then negatively charged particles will start
to move towards the positively charged area

203.text:
This causes the atomic equivalent of a motorway
pile up, with particles smashing into each

209.text:
other and -- with the xenon and neon gases
used in plasma screens, - releasing photons.

214.text: Or light, as we call it.

218.text:
Most of this light is ultraviolet, which is
invisible.

221.text:
But by coating those tiny cells with phosphoric
material, this can be changed into visible

226.text: light when it hits the side of the cells.

229.text:
Which it does a lot: a modern high-definition
display -- with 1920 pixels across and 1080

each being fired dozens of times a second
